title: Analyzing Workforce Dynamics and Safety: Insights from an Oil Refinery
Analyzing Workforce Dynamics and Safety: Insights from an Oil Refinery
text:
Loading Necessary Packages

# For data importing
library(readxl)

# For data manipulation and tidying
library(tidyverse)
library(stringr)

# For date and time handling
library(lubridate)

title: Analyzing Workforce Dynamics and Safety: Insights from an Oil Refinery
text:
Importing Data
The dataset for this project was sourced from an Excel file and imported into R using the read_excel() function from the readxl package. The imported data was then inspected and prepared for analysis through a series of cleaning and transformation steps to ensure accuracy and usability.

df <- read_excel("~/git_repos/solanillam/Project_2/Raw_Data/Copy of df_overall_final_V1.xlsx")

Ok, let’s take a look at the data set.

title: Welcome to My Web Page!
text:
This is my digital portfolio for STT 2860 - Intro to Data Management and Visualization. Here, you’ll find a showcase of the projects and visualizations I’ve created throughout this course. This work reflects my growing proficiency in data analysis, visual storytelling, and statistical tools.
But this portfolio isn’t just about my coursework—you’ll also get to learn more about me, my journey, and how this class has shaped my skills and aspirations.



Data Visualization

Arnholt, the instructor for STT 2860 - Introduction to Data Management and Visualization at Appalachian State University. To learn more about his teaching and access helpful resources, click here.

title: About Me
text:
Hello! I’m Mariana Solanilla, a passionate and driven individual who is excited to transition from my academic journey into the professional world. I’m graduating this December with a major in Psychology and a concentration in Human Services and a minor in Leadership Studies. Throughout my studies, I’ve developed a strong interest in understanding how people thrive in organizational settings and how effective leadership can foster a productive and inclusive environment.
Over the years, I’ve gained hands-on experience in human resources, safety analytics, and leadership, which has provided me with a broad set of skills that I’m eager to apply in a full-time role. I’ve worked on projects ranging from HR consulting to research on workplace safety, and I’ve had the opportunity to collaborate with diverse teams in both academic and professional settings.
I’m a first-generation college student with a deep commitment to personal growth, inclusivity, and fostering positive relationships both at work and in my personal life. I’m excited to apply what I’ve learned and continue growing as a professional in the workforce.
In my free time, I enjoy engaging in outdoor activities, photography, and reading to unwind and stay inspired. I look forward to connecting with like-minded professionals and contributing to an organization that values collaboration and innovation.
My Journey in STT 2860
As someone who has always been more drawn to people-oriented fields like psychology and leadership, diving into a course on data management and visualization felt like a bold step. But I’ve discovered just how powerful data can be in telling stories, identifying patterns, and supporting decision-making. This class has taught me to:

Approach challenges with a growth mindset.
See the beauty and creativity in data visualization.
Translate complex information into accessible insights.

Through perseverance and curiosity, I’ve gained a stronger foundation in data analysis, and I’m excited to carry these skills into my future endeavors.



Professional Headshot

title: Analyzing Workforce Dynamics and Safety: Insights from an Oil Refinery
text:
Data Munging

Step 1: Data Reduction

# Removed Unnecessary Columns
df_cleaned <- df %>% select(-aud, -obs, -turnaround)

# Removed Duplicate Rows
df_cleaned <- df_cleaned %>% distinct()

During the data reduction step, unnecessary columns (aud, obs, and turnaround) were removed to streamline the dataset and focus on relevant variables. Duplicate rows were eliminated to ensure the data was clean and free from redundancies, providing a solid foundation for accurate analysis.

title: Analyzing Workforce Dynamics and Safety: Insights from an Oil Refinery
text:
Data Munging (cleaning)

Step 1: Data Reduction

# Removed Unnecessary Columns
df_cleaned <- df %>% select(-aud, -obs, -turnaround)

# Removed Duplicate Rows
df_cleaned <- df_cleaned %>% distinct()

During the data reduction step, unnecessary columns (aud, obs, and turnaround) were removed to streamline the dataset and focus on relevant variables. Duplicate rows were eliminated to ensure the data was clean and free from redundancies, providing a solid foundation for accurate analysis.


Step 2: Data Validation

# Filtered Rows with Valid Values
df_cleaned <- df_cleaned %>%
  filter(!is.na(inc) & inc != 0) %>%
  filter(!is.na(ovt))
# Handled Outliers
df_cleaned <- df_cleaned %>%
  filter(ovt >= 0 & ovt <= 24)

Invalid rows with missing or zero incident values (inc) or missing overtime (ovt) were filtered out to ensure the dataset contained only meaningful observations. Outliers in overtime were handled by keeping only realistic values between 0 and 24 hours, maintaining the integrity of the data.


Step 3: Data Transformation

# Standardized Text Data
df_cleaned$unit <- trimws(toupper(df_cleaned$unit))

# Created New Variables
df_cleaned <- df_cleaned %>%
  mutate(total_work_time = hrs + ovt)

Text data in the unit column was standardized by trimming spaces and converting to uppercase for consistency. A new variable, total_work_time, was created to combine regular hours and overtime, enabling deeper analysis of workload patterns.

title: Analyzing Workforce Dynamics and Safety: Insights from an Oil Refinery
text:
Findings and Results

Incident Trends Over Time

# Incidents over time
df_incidents_over_time <- df_cleaned %>%
  group_by(date) %>%
  summarize(total_incidents = sum(inc, na.rm = TRUE))

ggplot(df_incidents_over_time, aes(x = date, y = total_incidents)) +
  geom_line(color = "red") +
  labs(title = "Incidents Over Time", x = "Date", y = "Total Incidents") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 55, hjust = 1, vjust = 1.0, size = 8)
  )










Workload Trends Over Time

# Time-Based Trend: Total Work Time Over Time
# Plot total work time over time
ggplot(df_cleaned, aes(x = date, y = total_work_time)) +
  geom_line(color = "blue") +
  labs(title = "Total Work Time Over Time", x = "Date", y = "Total Work Time (hrs)") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))










Incident Distribution Across Units

# Incident Distribution Across Units
# Bar plot of incidents across units
ggplot(df_cleaned, aes(x = unit, y = inc)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = "steelblue") +
  labs(title = "Incidents Across Units", x = "Unit", y = "Number of Incidents") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 55, hjust = 1, vjust = 1.0, size = 8)
  )










Workload Variability by Unit

# Average total work time by unit
df_avg_work_time <- df_cleaned %>%
  group_by(unit) %>%
  summarize(avg_work_time = mean(total_work_time, na.rm = TRUE))

ggplot(df_avg_work_time, aes(x = reorder(unit, avg_work_time), y = avg_work_time)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = "coral") +
  labs(title = "Average Total Work Time by Unit", x = "Unit", y = "Average Work Time (hrs)") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 55, hjust = 1, vjust = 1.0, size = 8)
  )+
  theme_minimal()










Relationship Between Hours Worked and Overtime

# Overtime vs. Hours Worked
# Scatter plot: Overtime vs. Hours Worked
ggplot(df_cleaned, aes(x = hrs, y = ovt)) +
  geom_point(color = "green", alpha = 0.6) +
  labs(title = "Overtime vs. Hours Worked", x = "Hours Worked", y = "Overtime (hrs)") +
  theme_minimal()
